item.title: Video Lecture 15 "How to Manage"
item.description: Hello everyone, Today I am going to review another video about how to start a startup. Today the guest lecturer is Ben Horowitz and he is going to speak about how to manage. Because of lack of time, he speaks only about one of the concepts of management, since according to him, that is where the majority of CEOs screw up. According to Ben, when making a critical decision, you have to understand how it’s going to be interpreted from every point of view.

item.title: Video Lecture 14 "How to Operate"
item.description: Hello everyone, Today I am going to review another video about how to start a startup. Today the guest lecturer is Aaron Levie who is going to talk about how to operate. According to Aaron, forging a company is much harder than forging a product, since people are irrational. Building an organization is essentially similar to taking all the irrational individuals you know placing them in one building, and after that living with them twelve hours per day.

item.title: Video Lecture 13 "How to be a Great Founder"
item.description: Hello everyone, today I am going to review another lecture about how to start a startup. This time the guest lecturer is Reid Hoffman, who appears to be the co-founder and current Executive chairman of the Linkedin. In this lecture he is telling about how to be a great founder. Reid started his lecture by stating that our picture about great founders is wrong, and that great founders do not have some kind of superpowers.

item.title: Video Lecture 12 "Building for the enterprise"
item.description: Hello everyone, Today I am going to review another video about how to start a startup. Today the guest lecturer is Aaron Levie who is the CEO and co-founder of the Box, and he is going to speak about building enterprise software. Box is a cloud content management and file sharing service for businesses. In the lecture Aaron talks about the history of the Box. According to him, at first they didn’t plan to create enterprise software, they just noticed that file sharing is was a really hard procedure and tried to fix that by creating the Box.

item.title: Video Lecture 11 "Hiring and culture"
item.description: Hello everyone, today’s video lecture’s guests are Patrick and John Collison and Ben Slibermann. This was more a Q&A than a usual lecture and this time, instead of reviewing the video I am going to write out the ideas that I liked. The decisions while you hire your first 10 employees are one of the mot important ones, as by hiring those 10 people, you are actually hiring 100 people.

item.title: Video Lecture 10 "Culture"
item.description: Hello everybody, after some delay I am going to review another video from Stanford University lectures. This time the gust speakers are Brian Chesky and Alfred Lin. The first speaker is Alfred Lin. According to Lin the company culture is Everyday core values and actions of each member of the team in pursuit of our mission. Honesty, integrity, service and teamwork are some core values of startup culture.

item.title: Video Lecture 9 "How to raise money"
item.description: Hello everyone! In this video lecture guests are Marc Andreessen, Ron Conwa and Parker Conra. This video lecture is more like a question and answer and honestly I don’t know how to review it. So I will not review this video, but what I will do is write in several points what I got out of this video. What I learned in this video lecture is: To get people invest in your company you must show that you are a leader, you are obsessed with your idea and you need the product as well

item.title: Video Lecture 8 "How to Get Started, Doing Things that Don't Scale, Press"
item.description: Hello everyone! Today’s video lecture’s speaker is Stanley Tang, who is the founder of DoorDash. Well, at first Stanley was telling about how everything started in DoorDash and how they tested whether delivery system was a good idea. What they did, is pretty simple! They just launched a demo website in an hour and tested if they would get orders. The main message Stanley tried to give was that you don’t need much to start a startup.

item.title: Video Lecture 7 "How to build products users love"
item.description: Hello everyone! Today I am going to write about all the useful things I learned from this video lecture. Today the speaker is Kevin Hale, who appears to be the CEO of Spectacle. Well, according to him, if you want to make billion dollars, you need to keep working on the values that helped you make your first dollar. You need to act with new users like you are trying to date them, and with existing users like you are trying to get married with them.

item.title: Video Lecture 6 "Growth"
item.description: Hello everybody! Today I am going to write all the stuff I find useful in this video lecture. Well, this time the speaker is Alex Schultz and he is speaking about Growth. What matters most for growth According to Alex the single most important thing for growth is retention. And for a good retention it is important to have a good product. Without a good product it is almost impossible to get good retention.

item.title: Video Lecture 5 "Competition is for losers"
item.description: Hey Everyone! In this post I am going to write about my takeaways from this lecture of Peter Thiel, who, if you don’t know, is the founder of PayPal and is going to talk about how to start a startup. So basically what peter concentrates on is that for a successful startup you need a market where you will have monopoly. For me, the interesting part in this video starts from the part about how to create a monopoly.

item.title: Video Lecture 4 "Building products..."
item.description: Hey everyone! In this post I am reviewing 4th lecture about how to start a startup. So, this time the lecturer is Adora Cheung and she speaks about Building Product, Talking to Users, and Growing. This time I am going to do things a bit different. Instead of reviewing the video lecture, I am going to write all the things I find interesting. I liked the part about the things people do wrong when starting a startup.

item.title: Video Lecture 3 "Before the Startup"
item.description: Hey everyone! In this post I am going to review another lecture about starting startups. The speaker in this lecture is Paul Graham, Co-Founder of Y combinator and my favorite news blog Hacker News. Paul once more highlights the importance of choosing the right team members. According to him we must choose team members as we would choose our friends. Another part I find important in the video is that you don’t need to be an expert in startups, you just need to work with your users in the right way.

item.title: Video Lectures 2 "Team and execution"
item.description: Hey everyone! In this post I am going to review the second lecture of the president of the Y Combinator Sam Altman regarding to starting startups. If you remember in the previous video Sam talked about the importance of the idea and the product in starting a startup. In this lecture he speaks about the next two aspects that you have to keep in mind while starting a startup.

item.title: Video lecture 1 review "How to start a startup"
item.description: This video’s first speaker is the president of Y Combinator Sam Altman. One of the biggest investment in IT are that Y Combinator had is its Hacker News website. As a daily user of the Hacker News it became more interesting for me what this guy will talk about. Well, I have to say that the talk was quite interesting and informative. He mainly talked about the four areas that you have to excel at to be able to start a successful startup.

item.title: My First Post
item.description: Hey there, I am Grigor. This is my blog for the “Start-up culture” course of AUA. Note that this is not my main blog and the github account associated with this blog is not my main account. You can find my main github page here: my github page This beautiful minimalistic blog was created by Hugo platform, using angels-ladder theme and was hosted in github pages. The code is open-source and available in https://github.
